publisher.publisher-name: Academy of Scientific Research and Technology, Egypt

title-group.article-title: Phytochemical screening and inhibitory effects of Catha edulis Forsk extracts on oxidation, growth, biofilm and quorum sensing of selected pathogens

contrib-group.aff: aDepartment of Applied Biology, School of Applied Natural Sciences (SoANS), Adama Science and Technology University, P. O. Box 1888, Adama, Ethiopia
bInstitute of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Adama Science and Technology University, P. O. Box 1888, Adama, Ethiopia
cDepartment of Biotechnology, Bule Hora University, P.O. Box 144, Bule Hora, Ethiopia

author-notes.corresp: ⁎Corresponding author at: Department of Applied Biology, School of Applied Natural Sciences (SoANS), Adama Science and Technology University, P. O. Box 1888, Adama, Ethiopia. mnaimuddin@gmail.com

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).

list-item.p: Phytochemical profiling of C. edulis extracts revealed antioxidants and antimicrobials.
MIC, MBC, MBIC and tolerance values of the extracts showed bactericidal properties.
Anti-quorum sensing activities of the extracts showed potency as valuable antimicrobials.
This is the first report of antibiofilm and anti-QS activities of C. edulis extracts on priority pathogenic bacteria.
The reduced antibiotic usage by replacement natural products may reduce AMR and MDR in pathogenic bacteria.

abstract.p: The treatment of infectious diseases is increasingly challenging due to the emergence and re-emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Plant-derived natural products are being explored as potential solutions to this global threat. This study investigated the phytochemical composition of Catha edulis and biological properties of its extracts, focusing on their potential as antioxidants and antimicrobials. Gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) of the methanol extract (MeOHE) fractions revealed 11 compounds in dichloromethane fraction (DCMF) and 30 compounds in ethyl acetate fraction (EAF), many of which possess bioactive functions as antioxidants and antimicrobials. Phytol was detected at 60.32 %, not reported before in C. edulis. The antioxidation potential of extracts was assayed by radical scavenging activity (RSA), and the IC50 values ranged from 68.2 to 89.3 µg/mL, respectively indicating good antioxidant potency. In the disc diffusion assay against representative pathogenic bacteria, the extracts exhibited an inhibition order of EAF > DCMF > MeOHE in the 31–75 % range. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) for MeOHE and DCMF were in the 0.5 − >1 mg/mL range, while the minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) were from 2 to > 2 mg/mL. EAF showed a MIC and MBC in the 0.5–––1 mg/mL and 1–––2 mg/mL range, suggesting better inhibition potential. The tolerance test values showed bactericidal activity against all the tested bacteria. The minimum biofilm inhibitory concentration (MBIC) values of DCMF were 250 to > 500 µg/mL, while EAF ranged from 125 to 500 µg/mL, indicating effective inhibition of biofilm formation. The anti-quorum sensing (anti-QS) activity of DCMF and EAF on P. aeruginosa showed 55.8 % and 51.4 % inhibition of pyocyanin production at 500 µg/mL. These results suggest that DCMF and EAF of C. edulis are potent antioxidants and antimicrobials, potentially reducing the load of pathogens. To our best knowledge, this is the first report of antibiofilm and anti-QS activities of C. edulis extracts on pathogenic bacteria included in the Pathogen Priority List.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The treatment of microbial infections by antimicrobials is one of the main approaches in modern medicine. However, when microorganisms face external pressure in the form of antimicrobial challenges, they tend to evolve combating mechanisms, leading to antimicrobial resistance (AMR), multidrug resistance (MDR), extensive drug resistance (XDR), and pandrug resistance (PDR).1 The massive resistant microbes pose a threat to treating infectious diseases and health of human, animal, and the environment.2, 3 AMR is a significant threat to global health due to the rising multidrug-resistant species identified by the World Health Organization.4 Microbes develop resistance due to increased genetic selection pressure caused by inappropriate use of antibiotics, easy availability of antibiotics, environmental release of nonmetabolized antibiotics, poor sanitation and increased international travel, resulting in the emergence and re-emergence of MDR species.1, 3 According to the Pathogen Priority List (PPL) published by WHO, the “critical priority” strains include Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacteriaceae resistant to carbapenems, and “High priority” strains include Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus faecium, Salmonella spp., Campylobacter spp., Helicobacter pylori, respectively resistant to methicillin, vancomycin.1, 4, 5, 6 These microbes cause infectious diseases such as urinary tract infection (UTI), ulcerative skin, lungs, and catheters that increases morbidity, mortality, and medical costs.7 Current antimicrobials have low performance or are ineffective against infections caused by AMR and MDR 1, 5.

Microbes can resist antimicrobial treatments through two main mechanisms: biofilm formation and quorum sensing (QS), which contribute to AMR and MDR.8, 9 Biofilms are multi-layered aggregates of microorganisms protected by extracellular polymeric substances (EPS). The cells adhere to a surface (living or inanimate), or each other, forming mobile biofilms.8 EPS are organic polymers made of polysaccharides, lipids, proteins and extracellular DNA (eDNA).10 These structured biofilms protect against adverse factors, and aid in adhesion, aggregation, nutrient absorption, water preservation, energy storage and enzymatic reactions in the bacteria, thus creating a thriving community inside the biofilm. Both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria can form biofilms that are incredibly resilient to the host immune system and antimicrobials. These biofilms allow the microbes to withstand significantly higher concentrations of antibiotics, making them a severe health hazard,11 which significantly drives up the cost of treatment. It is important to note that biofilm-related MDR bacteria substantially impact hospital environments, estimated to be responsible for 80 % of all microbial infections, including over 65 % of nosocomial infections.12 Due to biofilm formation, AMR is mainly caused by reduced permeability to antibiotics, drug efflux pumps, detoxification enzymes that inactivate antibiotics, and drug sequestration, preventing antibiotic-target interactions.13, 14, 15 QS is a crucial cell–cell communication system for regulation of biofilm formation, drug efflux pumps, virulence gene expression, and plasmid transfer.9, 13 The QS-regulated systems coordinate through diffusible autoinducer molecules, also known as QS signals. Gram-negative bacteria utilize N-acyl homoserine lactone (AHL), while Gram-positive bacteria employ autoinducing peptide (AIP) by interaction with specific proteins and enzymes such as LuxR-type activator proteins and LuxI-type synthases.14, 16 In P. aeruginosa, the QS circuits contain four distinct pathways, Las, Rh1, PQS, and IQS, producing their cognate AI molecules.16 The receptors and enzymes involved in these interactions or signalling can be exploited to develop or discover QS inhibitors crucial for reducing biofilms and developing treatment strategies 17.

The challenge of keeping up with the development of drug resistance in pathogens has led to the rise of AMR and MDR in treating infectious diseases. There is a pressing need for new combating strategies to tackle AMR and MDR infections. Some promising approaches being actively researched include antibodies, anti-microbial peptides (AMPs), vaccines, natural plant products, probiotics, and nanotechnology.1, 18, 19 Natural products extracted from plants and microbes are potential solutions, drawing from traditional uses.20 Plant natural products contain phenols, tannins, alkaloids, flavonoids, terpenoids, steroids, saponins, essential oils, lectins, and polypeptides. These bioactive molecules exhibit antimicrobial action by targeting different cellular processes, such as inhibition of cell wall synthesis, degradation of the cell wall and weakening membrane, leakage of intracellular proteins, oxidative DNA damage, and damage to intracellular organelles.20 Therefore, natural plant products offer various compounds that may help reduce or eliminate pathogenic bacteria in treating infections.

The current research focused on studying the phytochemistry of Catha edulis Forsk and its biological properties to investigate the potential of various extracts suitable as antioxidants and antimicrobials. C. edulis, also known as Khat, is an evergreen flowering Celestraceae plant commonly found in East Africa and the Southwest Arabian Peninsula. The leaves and twigs of khat are chewed for their natural psycho-stimulatory effect due to the presence of an alkaloid, cathinone.21 It also contains tannins, sterols, triterpenes, essential oils, vitamin C, niacin, thiamine, riboflavin, iron, and amino acids.22 Despite being a substance of abuse associated with social and medical controversies due to its adverse effects with long-term use, Khat seems to have potential as a medicinal plant.23, 24 Traditionally, processed leaves and roots of Khat have been used to treat diseases such as gastric ulcers, obesity, asthma, chest complications, depression, gonorrhea, and tiredness.24 However, the beneficial and therapeutic aspects have not been investigated, and there is not much information about the action mechanisms despite the richness in bioactive phytochemicals, vitamins, minerals, and amino acids. There are a few reports on the antimicrobial property of Khat,22 and only one report on its Streptococcus mutans antibiofilm activity,22 however, there are no reports of antibiofilm and anti-QS activities on the “ESKAPE” group and PPL pathogens to our knowledge. It is known that the chemical components of plant species and cultivars can vary according to soil structure, location, and environmental conditions,26 and may impact functions.25 Therefore, in this study, we investigated the phytochemicals of different extracts by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) from an indigenous C. edulis of Ethiopia and its inhibitory effects on oxidation, microbial growth, biofilm formation, and QS of selected pathogenic bacteria. We expect the results of this study will value the potential medicinal properties of C. edulis and contribute to combating resistant and pathogenic bacteria that cause fatal infectious diseases.

sec.title: Plant material
sec.p: The fresh plant, C. edulis, was collected in the month of February from local market of Hosanna located in Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's Region (SNNPR), Hadiya zone, Ethiopia at the latitude and longitude of 7°33′N 37°51′E with an elevation of 2177 m, respectively. The National Herbarium, Department of Botany, Addis Ababa University, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, authenticated the plant (Voucher No: YN001).

sec.title: Preparation of extracts
sec.p: Methanol extraction of C. edulis leaves was performed using maceration followed by ultrasonic assisted extraction (UAE). Fresh leaves were first washed thoroughly with distilled water followed by drying in the shade. The dried leaves were ground into powder. Three hundred grams of powder was mixed with 1.5 L of 99 % methanol (MeOH) and sonicated for 30 min, followed by maceration with intermittent shaking at 120 rpm for three days, and filtered. The filtered liquid was then concentrated at 40 °C (Rotary Evaporator, Henan Lanphan Technology Co. Ltd., China).

The methanol extract (MeOHE) underwent a liquid–liquid extraction process to obtain dichloromethane (DCM) and ethyl acetate (EA) fractions, following a previously described method with minor adjustments.27 Briefly, an equal volume of DCM was combined with MeOHE and shaken in a separating funnel. The mixture was then settled into two distinct layers with different compounds dissolved in their respective solvents. The bottom DCM layer was carefully separated, and fresh DCM was added to the separating funnel. This process was repeated until the DCM layer became completely clear. The DCMF was then dried using a rotary evaporator. The same procedure was followed for obtaining EAF.
The equation for calculating yield was:(1)%Y=W1W2×100%%Y = percent yield; W1 = weight of the leaf powder extract; and W2 = weight of the leaf powder prior to extraction.
The detailed procedures for qualitative phytochemical analysis of alkaloids, flavonoids, phenols, saponins, steroids, tannins, terpenoids and glycosides are provided in the Supporting Information.

sec.title: GC/MS analyses
sec.p: GC/MS was done using an Agilent Technologies, USA system (model GC 7890B coupled with MS 5977A Network). The analysis was done using a HP-5MS column (30 m × 0.25 mm internal diameter and 0.25 μm film thickness). The carrier gas was helium. The injection method used was splitless, with a purge time of one minute and a solvent delay of four minutes. The temperature was increased from 110 to 330 °C with a flow rate of 1.2 mL/min and a run time of 33 min. Mass spectra were obtained by scanning the 33–550 m/z range in electron-impact mode with an ionization energy of 70 eV.28 Compound identification was conducted by comparing the mass spectra with those in the NIST11 GC–MS libraries 29.

sec.title: Antioxidation activity
sec.p: To investigate the antioxidant activity of the extracts, we utilized the free radical scavenging assay based on 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH).30 Methanol was used to prepare 0.1 mM DPPH solution and stored in a dark bottle for 30 min. The serial dilutions of DCMF and EAF prepared from 1.95 to 1000 µg/mL concentrations. The standard reference was ascorbic acid, and the negative control was DPPH solution. In brief, the samples as well as positive controls (3 mL) were mixed with DPPH solution (1 mL) by gentle shaking and incubated at room temperature for 30 min in the dark. The absorbance measurements were performed at a wavelength of 517 nm (Optizen 2120UV, Mecasys Co. Ltd., South Korea). The equation for calculating radical scavenging activity is as follows.(2)%RSA=Ao-A1Ao×100%%RSA = percent radical scavenging activity, A0 = absorbance of the blank DPPH, and A1 = sample.30, 31 The results were processed as Inhibitory concentration (IC50) that correspond to 50 % RSA.

sec.title: Antibacterial activity
sec.p: The agar disc diffusion assay was performed to determine the antibacterial activity of MeOHE, DCMF, and EAF. The tested pathogenic bacteria were two Gram-positive, S. pyogenes (ATCC 12204) and S. aureus (ATCC 25923) and two Gram-negative strains, E. coli (ATCC 25922), P. aeruginosa (ATCC 27853), respectively. These strains are known to possess antimicrobial resistance, and are used for antibiotic susceptibility tests (source: American Type Culture Collection). The strains were obtained from Adama Regional Laboratory, Adama, Ethiopia. The MeOHE, DCMF and EAF were diluted to prepare 100, 50, 25, and 12.5 mg/mL in 10 % Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as a solvent. Initially, the test bacterial strains were inoculated on Muller-Hinton Agar (MHA) plates for activation. Then, inocula development was performed by inoculating a single colony into Muller-Hinton Broth (MHB) followed by incubation at 37 °C for 24 h (ThermoStable SIR-250, Daihan Scientific Co. Ltd., South Korea). The fresh bacterial cultures and sub-cultures were maintained at 0.5 McFarland standards to contain 1.5 × 108 colony-forming units (CFU/mL). The overnight culture strains were swabbed uniformly over MHA plates. Then, sterile discs (6 mm diameter) containing different concentrations of MeOHE, DCMF and EAF (12.5–100 mg/mL) were placed on the swabbed plates, and incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. The positive control disc was Ciprofloxacin (30 µg/mL) and negative control disc was 10 % DMSO, respectively. The zone of inhibition diameter (mm) was measured to determine the antimicrobial activity. The inhibition activity was normalized as percentage relative inhibition (%RI) using Eq. 3 19, 31.(3)%RI=diameterofsample(mm)/diameterofcontrol(mm)×100

sec.title: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) and minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC)
sec.p: The broth dilution method was performed for the determination of MIC and MBC. The MeOHE, DCMF and EAF dilutions were prepared in 10 % DMSO. Working dilutions were then prepared in 10 mL of LB broth to achieve concentrations ranging from 1000 to 125 µg/mL. A 100 μL inoculum was mixed gently from McFarland standard broth (5 × 106 CFU/mL) and incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. The extract concentration that inhibited the visible growth of bacteria was recorded as MIC. Following this, 20 μL inoculum starting from MIC to higher concentrations were spread on MH agar Petri plates and incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. The concentration of the extract that caused complete inhibition of the bacterial growth on the agar Petri plates was determined as MBC 32.

sec.title: Minimum biofilm inhibitory concentration (MBIC)
sec.p: The anti-biofilm assay was carried out according to previously described method with minor modifications.33 Briefly, bacterial culture media with an optical density (O.D.) of 0.05 (5 × 105 CFU per mL) was mixed with varying concentrations of DCMF and EAF in 10 mL test tubes followed by incubation at 37 °C for 48 h. The extract concentrations started from MIC and were lowered to sub-MIC (500–62.5 µg/mL). After incubation, the non-adherent cells were washed out with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and 1 % crystal violet (CV) was used to stain the adherent cells for ten minutes, followed by removal of excess stain with PBS. The tubes were air-dried, and solubilization of CV stained biofilm was achieved with 33 % glacial acetic acid. A control without extract treatment was prepared using similar procedure to quantify the adherent cells. Absorbance measurements were performed at 590 nm, and the percent biofilm formation was calculated according to Eq. 4.(4)Biofilmformation(%)=OD590sampleOD590Control×100%The inhibition of a minimum of 50 % biofilm formation yielded Minimum Biofilm Inhibitory Concentration (MBIC) 31, 33.

sec.title: Anti-QS activity
sec.p: Pyocyanin is a pigment produced by P. aeruginosa that plays important roles in virulence and antibiotic resistance, and is regulated by QS. Thus, the inhibition of pyocyanin production gives a measure of anti-QS activity.31, 34 The pyocyanin inhibition assay (PIA) involved adding different dilutions (sub-MIC) of DCMF and EAF to 6 mL cultures of P. aeruginosa followed by incubation at 37 °C for 24 h. Then, 2 mL of chloroform was mixed and subjected to centrifugation (5,000 rpm for five minutes). The solubilization of organic layer was achieved by addition of two mL of 0.2 M HCl, and absorbance measurements were performed at 520 nm. A control sample that did not contain the extract was used as the reference (100 %), and a blank sample was prepared by mixing distilled water with 0.2 M HCl.31, 34 The inhibition percentage was calculated using Eq. 5.(5)%Pyocyanininhibition=OD520ofcontrol-OD520oftreatedOD520ofcontrol×100%

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Results of three independent experiments were presented as the mean ± standard deviation (SD). P values less than 0.05 were used to determine the statistical significance. For all statistical analyses, we used Microsoft Excel 2010 and SPSS statistical software.

sec.title: Phytochemicals analysis (Qualitative and quantitative)
sec.p: The C. edulis leaves were extracted with methanol (MeOHE) and fractionated with dicholoromethane (DCMF) and ethyl acetate (EAF), respectively. The MeOHE yield was 20.8 %, and the yields from fractions were 7 % (DCMF) and 5 % (EAF), respectively. In the qualitative biochemical analysis of MeOHE, terpenoids, flavonoids, alkaloids, tannins and phenols were present, however, steroids were absent (Table S1). In C. edulis, tannins are reported in relatively high amounts (8–25.4 %) 35.

The phytochemical composition of the extracts was determined by GC/MS analyses using standard protocols. Due to the polarity of compounds, GC/MS of MeOHE was not performed directly as the technique provides non-polar and volatile compounds. The MeOHE compatibility was solved by fractionation with DCMF and EAF that were compatible with GC/MS.36 A total of 11 (DCMF) and 30 (EAF) compounds were detected, respectively. The chromatograms of the extracts are shown in Fig. 1. The identification of major compounds was determined by the peak intensity in chromatograms (Fig. 1), and compared to match with those in the NIST11 GC–MS libraries. The results are presented in Table 1 (DCMF) and Table 2 (EAF), respectively (complete list of compounds of EAF is included in Table S2. The peak areas of the individual compounds were analysed to calculate percent abundance (amount). The major compounds found in DCMF were phytol (60.32 %; NIST11 match percentage, 89.64), benzyl carbazate (20.8 %; NIST11 match%, 76.78), squalene (4.46 %; NIST11 match%, 69.79), eicosyl octyl ether (4.43 %; NIST11 match%, 75.19), octadecane P630 (3.83 %; NIST11 match%, 56.85) and neophytadiene (2.8 %; NIST11 match%, 91.4), respectively (Table 1). The major compounds detected in EAF were (24R)-Stigmast-5-en-3.beta.-ol (31.43 %; NIST11 match%, 80.65), β-Amyrin (27.51 %; NIST11 match%, 72.53), 6a,14a-Methanopicene, perhydro-1,2,4a,6b,9,9,12a-heptamethyl-10-hydroxy- (7.81 %; NIST11 match%, 53.24), 7,9-Di-tert-butyl-1-oxaspiro (4,5)deca-6,9-diene-2,8-dione (4.31 %; NIST11 match%, 56.85), dibutyl phthalate (3.97 %; NIST11 match%, 56.85), squalene (3.8 %; NIST11 match%, 63.06), alpha-tocopheryl acetate (3.04 %; NIST11 match%, 77.64), 9,12,15-octadecatrienoic acid, methyl ester (2.39 %; NIST11 match%, 85.96), and palmitic acid P639 (1.2 %; NIST11 match%, 77.15), respectively (Table 2).Fig. 1
GC–MS chromatograms of DCMF (A) and EAF (B) of C. edulis. The peaks indicate the abundance of compounds. Retention time is shown by the numbers above peaks.Table 1

sec.title: Antioxidant activity
sec.p:
The inhibition of oxidation by MeOHE, DCMF and EAF was determined by using the DPPH free radical scavenging activity. The results indicate that all extracts effectively scavenged free radicals in the 1.95–1000 μg/mL concentration range. The scavenging activities of MeOHE, DCMF and EAF were dose-dependent, and the IC50 values were 89.3 ± 7.2, 76.7 ± 5.4 and 68.2 ± 4.1 µg/mL, respectively (Table 3). The IC50 of ascorbic acid, used as the standard reference, was 9.5 ± 1.2 µg/mL.Table 3
Antioxidant activity of MeOHE, DCMF, and EAF of C. edulis.
MeOHEDCMFEAFAscorbic acid
IC50 (µg/mL)89.3 ± 7.276.7 ± 5.468.2 ± 4.19.5 ± 1.2
IC50, concentration at which 50% inhibition observed.

sec.title: Antimicrobial activity of extracts
sec.p:
The antimicrobial potency of MeOHE, DCMF and EAF was tested on four bacterial strains at various concentrations (12.5–100 mg/mL) using agar disc diffusion assay. The Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria were included by their pathogenic relevance and AMR potential. All the extracts, MeOHE, DCMF and EAF inhibited all the bacterial strains with varying degrees of inhibition at the tested concentrations (Table 4). Representative bacteria from both the bacterial classes were inhibited at higher concentrations in a dose-dependent pattern. However, in MeOHE and DCMF, the Gram-negative strains did not show susceptibility at lower concentrations (12.5 and 25 mg/mL). EAF was effective at all the tested concentrations in all strains except E. coli (no inhibition at 12.5 mg/mL). The zones of inhibition (ZOI) were normalized to percent inhibition with respect to control (see Materials and Methods section). The MeOHE showed inhibition in the 31–62 % range, the DCMF range was 33–70 %, and EAF was in 32–75 % range, respectively, indicating an order of EAF > DCMF > MeOHE.Table 4
Average inhibition zone and percentage inhibition of the C. edulis extracts.

Values are the mean values of three independent experiments. The mean diameter values were rounded off to the nearest number.

sec.title: MIC and MBC
sec.p:
The ability of the extracts to cause cytotoxicity to bacteria is evaluated by MIC and MBC. The concentration of a substance that causes inhibition of visible growth of a bacterium is determined as the MIC, and the concentration that kills the bacterium is determined as the MBC. Thus, in order to determine the potential as an antibacterial, it is important to evaluate the effectiveness of substance at low concentrations. The potency of the extracts is indicated by the tolerance test (ratio of MBC and MIC), where a value of > 4 indicates bacteriostatic activity and values < 4 indicates bactericidal potential. The results of MIC and MBC assays for MeOHE, DCMF and EAF are presented in Table 5. For MeOHE, the MIC values ranged from 0.5-1.0 mg/mL and MBCs from 1-2 mg/mL, respectively. E.coli exhibited MIC of 1 mg/mL (lower susceptibility) and P. aeruginosa (MeOHE, 0.5 mg/mL) and S. pyogenes (DCMF, 0.5 mg/mL) demonstrated susceptibility to MeOHE and DCMF. On the other hand, S. aureus recorded > 1 mg/mL (ND, not detectable in the tested range) values for both MeOHE and DCMF, suggesting higher resistance. The same trend was observed for MBC, and most strains recorded MBC of 2 mg/mL, with S. aureus > 2 mg/mL (ND), respectively. However, EAF was effective against most strains, with a MIC of 0.5 mg/mL, except for E. coli (1 mg/mL), which showed lower susceptibility. The MBC values were also comparatively lower (1–2 mg/mL). The EAF result also indicated that Gram-negative strains were more resistant than Gram-positive bacteria; however, more rigorous tests are required, such as including more strains for a safe conclusion. Thus, MIC values indicate the following order: EAF < DMCF or MeOHE. The tolerance test (MBC/MIC) values were found between 2 and 4; values of < 4 indicate bactericidal potency 37.Table 5
MIC, MBC, and MBC/MIC of MeOHE, DCMF, and EAF of C. edulis.

ND, not detectable in the tested range. The values are from three independent experiments (P < 0.05).

sec.title: Antibiofilm activity and MBIC
sec.p:
The formation of biofilms is commonly associated with resistance to antimicrobials giving rise to AMR and MDR pathogens and cause diseases that are difficult or impossible to treat. Therefore, new pharmaceutical sources are essential for effectively inhibiting and eradicating biofilms to treat disease conditions.17 The DCMF and EAF of C. edulis were evaluated for their antibiofilm activity and MBIC values were determined. The concentration of the test extract that causes a minimum of 50 % reduction of biofilm is determined as MBIC. The results are presented in Fig. 2, Fig. 3. MeOHE was not included in antibiofilm assays based on lower activities from the disc diffusion and MIC/MBC assays. Both DCMF and EAF showed potency to reduce biofilm formation by the tested strains with dose dependency.Fig. 2
Qualitative results of biofilm formation and inhibition. The bacterial cultures forming biofilm were treated with different concentrations of DCMF and EAF of C. edulis and stained using CV staining method. The concentration of extracts varied from 62.5 – 500 µg/mL.Fig. 3
Quantitative analysis of antibiofilm assay of DCMF and EAF. Different bacterial strains were tested for the biofilm formation ability in the presence of varying concentrations of DCMF (left) and EAF (right). After staining and destaining of biofilms, CV solutions were measured spectrophotometrically. The inhibition of biofilm formation was dose-dependent on the extract concentrations. Three independent experiments were performed (P < 0.05).

In DCMF, Gram-positive representative bacteria (S. aureus and S. pyogenes) showed considerable reduced formation of biofilms with MBIC values of 500 µg/mL (40.36 % biofilm formation) (S. aureus) and 250 µg/mL (38.14 % biofilm formation) (S. pyogenes), respectively. However, Gram-negative representative bacteria (P. aeruginosa and E. coli) were resistant to DCMF with MBIC values of > 500 µg/mL. At 500 µg/mL, P. aeruginosa and E. coli showed 62.88 % and 63.17 % biofilm formation. Thus, for DCMF, the inhibition of biofilm formation followed the order: S. pyogenes > S. aureus > P. aeruginosa > E. coli. EAF was more efficient and significantly reduced the biofilm formation with lower MBICs. Gram-positive bacteria showed higher susceptibility and recorded lower MBIC values of 250 µg/mL (42.52 %) (S. aureus) and 125 µg/mL (35.29 %) (S. pyogenes), respectively. S. pyogenes showed the highest susceptibility as biofilm formation was reduced to 12.45 and 10.91 % at 250 µg/mL and 500 µg/mL, respectively (Fig. 2, Fig. 3). S. aureus also showed higher reduction of biofilm formation and susceptibility when treated with EAF compared to DCMF. The biofilm formation by P. aeruginosa, a Gram-negative strain, was also reduced considerably under EAF treatment, recording MBIC of 500 µg/mL (38.95 %). However, the other Gram-negative strain, E. coli, was resistant to EAF with MBIC of > 500 µg/mL (61.47 %). Thus, for EAF, the inhibition of biofilm formation followed the order of S. pyogenes > S. aureus > P. aeruginosa > E. coli.

sec.title: Antiquorum sensing activity of DCMF and EAF
sec.p:
P. aeruginosa contains a distinctive pigment, pyocyanin that plays critical roles in infection and virulence via QS. Pyocyanin has a positive relationship with antibiotic resistance34 and inhibition of pyocyanin production has been utilized to study the anti-QS properties of inhibitors.34, 38 Pyocyanin inhibition assay (PIA) in the model bacteria, P. aeruginosa, is often employed to evaluate QS activity.39 In this study, effective inhibition of pyocyanin production was observed by both DCMF (22–55.8 %) and EAF (19.8–51.4 %) using PIA in the 62.5–500 µg/mL concentration range (Fig. 4).Fig. 4
Pyocyanin inhibition assay. P. aeruginosa was challenged with increasing concentrations of DCMF and EAF. Inhibition of pyocyanin production was monitored spectrophotometrically, and observed to be dose-dependent. Values represent three independent experiments (P < 0.05).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Microorganisms can develop resistance when exposed to antimicrobials used to treat human and animal diseases. Therefore, finding new alternative treatment methods for AMR is crucial. In this study, the extracts of C. edulis cultivar of Ethiopia were used to determine their phytochemical composition and their effects on oxidation, microbial growth, biofilm formation, and QS of selected pathogenic bacteria.

In GC/MS technique, the samples are bombarded with electrons to produce positively charged ions from organic or inorganic compounds at high temperatures (GC), and then, separation of the ions is achieved according to their mass-to-charge (m/z) ratio in column (MS). The compounds are detected qualitatively and quantitatively based on their m/z (retention time) and adundance.28 Helium is used as the carrier gas due to its higher performance and inert characteristics. The GC/MS analyses of DCMF and EAF detected 11 and 30 compounds, respectively. In DCMF, the major compounds identified were phytol, benzyl carbazate, squalene, eicosyl octyl ether, octadecane P630 and neophytadiene. Phytol, is a diterpene member of long-chain unsaturated acyclic alcohols and is biologically active as antibacterial, antioxidant, antitumor, anti-inflammatory, antiallergic, antinociceptive and immunostimulatory effects.39, 40, 41, 42 The mechanism of action of phytol was elucidated and shown to induce oxidative stress to cause antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa.42 Phytol was reported at < 2.5 % abundance in methanol and DMSO extracts of C. edulis Forsk.43 However, in this study, it was found in significantly higher abundance at 60.32 %. In another report, it was observed at higher abundance (87.7 %) in Lacistema pubescens with antiparasitic function.44 This may be due to the environmental growth conditions and soil structure of different places.26 Benzyl carbazate was another primary compound detected in high abundance (20.8 %) that has useful antioxidant property and pharmaceutical applications such as inhibitor of enzymes like acetylcholinesterase, GAPDH.45 It is also used as a precursor for the synthesis of pharmaceutical ingredients. Squalene, a triterpene, is reported to have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and anti-atheroschlerotic properties.46 Octadecane exhibits antibacterial and antifungal properties.47, 48 Neophytadiene, a diterpenoid compound, is reported for antimicrobial, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antibiofilm properties.49, 50 Most of the major compounds in DCMF of C. edulis are potentially bioactive as antioxidants and antimicrobials. Thus, DCMF may likely exhibit experimental bioactivity.

The major compounds found in EAF also have known biological activities. (24R)-Stigmast-5-en-3betaol (β-sitosterol) (31.43 %) exists naturally in plants cells and is bioactive as antioxidant and antibacterial.51.52 β-amyrin (27.51 %) is a pentacyclic triterpene distributed in the leaves and stems. It acts as an antimicrobial agent by inducing the production of reactive oxygen species in microorganisms and cause cell lysis.53, 54 Antioxidant activity has been reported for 6a,14a-Methanopicene, perhydro-1,2,4a,6b,9,9,12a-heptamethyl-10-hydroxy-; and 7,9-Di-tert-butyl-1-oxaspiro (4,5)deca-6,9-diene-2,8- dione.55, 56 Dibutyl phthalate and 9,12,15-Octadecatrienoic acid (α-linolenic acid) possess antibacterial properties.57, 58 α-tocopherol acts as an antioxidant and modulates antibacterial activity.59 Palmitic acid is known for its antibacterial effects.60 Most of the major compounds in EAF of C. edulis are bioactive. Thus, EAF may likely exhibit antioxidant and antimicrobial bioactivities.

The antioxidation potential of the extracts were tested by DPPH free radical scavenging assay. This method is based on the principle of reduction of DPPH by hydrogen donors to diphenyl picrylhydrazine. In this assay, the extracts were capable of efficiently removing free radicals with IC50 values in the range of 68.2 to 89.3 µg/mL. This may be attributed to the compounds that possess antioxidation property such as phytol, squalene, neophytadiene (DCMF); and β-sitosterol, squalene, α-tocopherol, 6a,14a-Methanopicene, perhydro-1,2,4a,6b,9,9,12a-heptamethyl-10-hydroxy-, and 7,9-Di-tert-butyl-1-oxaspiro (4,5)deca-6,9-diene-2,8-dione (EAF), respectively found in this study by GC/MS. The antioxidant property of natural products of plants have been reported in several studies,31, 61 and take part in scavenging free radicals involved in several metabolic pathways and disease states. This important property provides various beneficial effects, including immunoprotective, neuroprotective, anticancerous and hepatoprotective effects 55, 62.

The three extracts investigated effectively inhibited all the tested bacterial strains in the order of EAF > DCMF > MeOHE. The lower inhibition of MeOHE may be due to the lower concentration of molecules. DCMF and EAF underwent a second fractionation step which may have concentrated the molecules in the extraction environment of the solvents. In a previous report, higher inhibitory activities were reported for the fractions than MeOHE from which the fractionation was performed.53 The plant extracts showed variable antibacterial activities that may be specific or broad-spectrum.63 There were no apparent differences in the susceptibility patterns of Gram-positive and Gram-negative strains against the extract/fractions, although Gram-positive strains appear slightly more susceptible. The Gram-positive bacterial cell walls contain teichoic acids that partially impart a negative charge and allow the passage of positively charged molecules, and interact with charged proteins in the cell wall. This may damage and rupture the cells, causing higher antibacterial activity in Gram-positive bacteria. However, the composition of Gram-negative bacterial cell wall is complex and protected by a second membrane that restricts the passage of molecules, and thereby plausibly imparts resistance against antibacterials.64 At 100 mg/mL, S. pyogenes showed the highest susceptibility (75 %, EAF), while E. coli showed the least susceptibility (or higher resistance) (51 %, MeOHE) among all the tested strains. In EAF, S. pyogenes and P. aeruginosa showed higher dose-dependent inhibition in the 27–73 % and 32–75 % range, followed by S. aureus (33–64 %) and E. coli (NA-56 %), respectively. Even though the susceptibility pattern is unclear, all the extracts potentially inhibited the tested strains that indicate broad spectrum activity. The compounds listed in Table 1, Table 2 such as phytol, octadecane, and neophytadiene (DCMF); and β-sitosterol, β-amyrin, α-linolenic acid, dibutyl phthalate, α-tocopherol and palmitic acid (EAF) have known antibacterial properties39, 47, 49, 51, 53, 57, 60 that appears to be responsible, at least in part, for the inhibition of bacterial strains. The other compounds in the complete list present in minor amounts may also be responsible for or synergistically contribute to the observed antibacterial activity (Table 1, DCMF; Table S2, EAF). Noteworthy, P. aeruginosa is categorized as “critical priority” strains; and S. aureus as a “high priority” strain in the Pathogen Priority List (PPL) of WHO 4.

In previous studies, antibacterial activity of the aqueous extract of C. edulis was found only in Gram-positive bacteria. However, no activity was observed against MDR strains such as S. aureus.22 Fatima et al. reported that methanol and DMSO extracts are potentially active as antibacterials against Gram-positive as well as Gram-negative bacteria, including MDR strains.43 Interestingly, they also found high activity against S. pyogenes which was tested to be resistant against several antibiotics, in comparison with other strains. In this study, MeOHE and its fractions (DCMF and EAF) inhibited bacterial growth, with broad spectrum, that included resistant strains like S. aureus and P. aeruginosa. The highest susceptible strain was S. pyogenes. The effectiveness of the extract and fractions against these stringent and MDR strains, including other resistant strains (E. coli and S. pyogenes) may be considered as valuable for their potential and further studies to combat infections caused by these pathogenic bacteria.

The quantitative inhibition assay was performed by broth dilution method to determine MIC and MBC. The MIC values of EAF were comparatively lower and more effective. The following order was observed: EAF < DMCF or MeOHE. In general, MICs varied between 0.5 − >1 mg/mL and MBCs were in the 0.5 − >2 mg/mL range. A previous report documented the MIC values of aqueous extract of C. edulis for S. pyogenes ranging from 10-20 mg/mL. In this study, the MICs of EAF and DCMF for S. pyogenes were 0.5 mg/mL, better than the reported values.22 The MIC and MBC values in 0.5–2.0 mg/mL range may represent moderate to high activity. A study using 239 traditional Chinese extracts reported MIC values in the 0.10 to 12.5 mg/mL range and MBC values of 0.78 to 25 mg/mL.65 Our results agree with these values in the lower range, indicating effectiveness of DCMF and EAF. The tolerance test values for all the extracts were in the 2–4 range, indicating bactericidal activity,37 and support the MIC/MBC data. Thus, DCMF and EAF may prove efficient against resistant and MDR bacterial species, and justify further studies.

The antibiofilm studies of C. edulis revealed that both extracts effectively reduced the biofilm formation ability of the tested bacteria. In general, biofilm forming ability of Gram-positive strains was more affected than Gram-negative bacteria. Significant biofilm reduction was observed, and MBICs were in the 0.125–0.5 mg/mL range. S. pyogenes showed the highest reduction (approximately 90 %) at 0.5 mg/mL. In a previous study, the antibiofilm activity of C. edulis aqueous extract was studied on Streptococcus mutans, and reported MBIC values in the 2.5–10 mg/mL range.22 However, there are no reports of the effect of C. edulis extracts on the PPL category pathogenic bacteria. This study found effective inhibition of biofilm-formers (included in the PPL category) with MBICs in the 0.125–0.5 mg/mL range. The MBICs of MeOHE of different plant extracts were reported in the 0.125–100 mg/mL wide range. The results of this study are in agreement in the 0.125–1.0 mg/mL range.66, 67 These results suggest that both DCMF and EAF effectively reduced biofilm formation, with EAF showing slightly more pronounced effect than DCMF. It is noteworthy that the antibiofilm activities of extracts of C. edulis is reported for the first time in this study. Therefore, both fractions, particularly EAF, show promise in extracting effective molecules from C. edulis and may be further studied to develop potent antimicrobials against resistant pathogenic bacteria, thereby reducing the medical burden and cost of treatment.

QS plays critical roles in virulence, biofilms, antibiotic resistance and plamid transfer.9, 13 Therefore, QS is an important target in developing antimicrobials. Inhibiting QS activities can decrease bacterial populations.16, 17 The potency of the extracts as QS inhibitors was examined using PIA in P. aeruginosa. At 500 µg/mL, pyocyanin production was inhibited 55.8 % (DCMF) and 51.4 % (EAF), respectively. In a previous study, at 750 µg/mL, pyocyanin production was inhibited by Camellia nitidissima extracts in the 51.25–67.5 % range.68 Our results are in agreement with this study. Phytol, also found in the DCMF of this study, is a highly potent inhibitor (MIC-19 µg/mL) of production of pyocyanin.39 Similarly, β –sitosterol and β-amyrin, also found in EAF, are reported as potent QS inhibitor.69, 70 Thus, the anti-QS potential of DCMF and EAF may be due to strong inhibitors such as phytol, β-sitosterol and β-amyrin, respectively. It is noteworthy that the anti-QS activities of extracts of C. edulis is reported for the first time. Based on these results, DCMF and EAF may be justified for further investigations to develop as QS inhibitors..

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Microorganisms develop AMR and MDR when challenged with antimicrobials. Plant natural products are possible solutions to combat resistant pathogens that cause various fatal diseases. In this study, we explored the phytochemical composition of C. edulis and its potential for antimicrobial properties against four pathogenic bacterial strains. The phytochemical screening by GC/MS identified several bioactive compounds with antioxidant, antimicrobial and other important physiological roles. Phytol was detected at 60.32 % abundance, and reported for the first time in C. edulis. The methanol extract and its fractions, DCMF and EAF, showed good inhibitory activities against all the tested bacteria. The important parameters, antioxidation, MIC, MBC, tolerance test, MBIC, and anti-QS activity indicated high inhibitory potential of all the extracts. Among the extracts, DCMF and EAF are potent and valuable as antioxidants and antimicrobials. However, these fractions should be tested against various bacteria for a safer conclusion. The individual compounds may be purified and investigated alone or to find synergistic combinations. Furthermore, different approaches may be combined to find new or improved molecules of high therapeutic values to combat AMR, MDR, and pathogenic microbes. The use of natural medicinal products may help to reduce AMR and MDR in pathogenic bacteria.

sec.p: Yonatan Nesru: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. Muktar Ahmed: Writing – review & editing, Methodology, Investigation. Adam Mengistu: Writing – review & editing. Mohammed Naimuddin: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Formal analysis, Conceptualization.
